column1: Public Performance Measure (PPM): Proportion of trains arriving on time: Train Operating Companies franchised by the Department for Transport (DfT)
Percentage of trains arriving on time in rail period
Percentage of trains arriving on time moving annual average
Figures for the latest period are provisional.

PPM figures are published by rail period. There are 13 four week long rail periods in a year. The lengths of the first and last rail periods in the year are varied so that the first period of the year always starts on 1 April, the start of the financial year, and all other periods start on a Sunday.

A train is considered to be on time if it arrives at its destination within five minutes (i.e. four minutes 59 seconds or less) of the planned arrival time for London and South East and regional operators; or ten minutes (i.e. nine minutes 59 seconds or less) for long-distance operators.
From 2006/07 period 1 First TransPennine Express was re-classified to the long-distance sector for performance purposes, so figures before and after this point are not directly comparable.
